content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, I would consider this game a form of strategic interaction, where both players can potentially benefit from knowing each other's strategies. Since we are anonymous, it is reasonable to assume that there is no way for me to know my opponent's strategy in advance. In this situation, I will adopt a strategy known as the Tit-for-Tat strategy, which involves starting with cooperation and then mimicking my opponent's previous move.

In this game, choosing R yields higher payoffs when my opponent chooses B (35$), but there is also a risk of earning no money if they also choose R. Conversely, choosing B guarantees 40$ in each round but only earns 35$ when my opponent chooses R.

Considering the Tit-for-Tat strategy:

1. In the first round, I might pick R to start with cooperation, and if my opponent responds with R as well, I will reciprocate by choosing R for the rest of the game. This results in a total payoff of 45$ (one round) + 0$ (the remaining 74 rounds) = 45$.
2. If my opponent starts with B, I would mimic their strategy and pick B for the entire game, earning a total payoff of 40$ * 75 = 3000$.

Given that we do not have any prior information about our opponent's strategy, adopting the Tit-for-Tat strategy allows us to maximize potential payoffs by starting with cooperation and then reciprocating our opponent's moves. In this case, I would choose R as my initial move: {R}.
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 35$. Please play the next round.

Since my opponent chose B in the first round, I will reciprocate and choose B for the second round based on the Tit-for-Tat strategy. This guarantees me a payoff of 40$ if my opponent continues to pick B. If they change their strategy to R, I will switch back to R in response, following the same strategy I adopted initially.
